title: David Duckenfield arrives for manslaughter retrial over Hillsborough disaster
text:
Hillsborough match commander David Duckenfield has arrived at court ahead of his retrial over the 1989 football stadium disaster.

The former South Yorkshire Police superintendent, 75, denies the manslaughter by gross negligence of 95 Liverpool fans at the FA Cup semi-final at Sheffield Wednesday's Hillsborough stadium on April 15, 1989.

His trial at Preston Crown Court is expected to last up to seven weeks.

David Duckenfield, who was the police match commander during the Hillsborough disaster, is to appear at the retrial for 95 counts of manslaughter by gross negligence

Duckenfield's retrial at Preston Crown Court is expected to last around six weeks

The prosecution case is likely to be opened later in the week.

Ninety-six men, women and children died in the crush in pens at the Leppings Lane end of the Sheffield Wednesday ground at the match between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest.

Under the law at the time, there can be no prosecution for the death of the 96th victim, Tony Bland, as he died more than a year and a day after his injuries were caused.
description: The former South Yorkshire Police superintendent, 75, denies the manslaughter by gross negligence of 95 Liverpool fans at the FA Cup semi-final on April 15 1989.
